Detailed Description

A time interpolator defines the rate of change of an animation.

This allows animations to have non-linear motion, such as acceleration and deceleration.

 TimeInterpolator *interpolator = new AccelerateDecelerateInterpolator();
 ObjectValue *animator = ObjectValue::ofFloatN(myObject, "x", 2, 0.0f, 100.0f);
 animator->setInterpolator(interpolator);
 animator->setDuration(500);
 animator->start();

 delete animator;
 delete interpolator;

Member Function Documentation

virtual float gaia::core::ITimeInterpolator::getInterpolation ( float  input) [pure virtual]

Maps a value representing the elapsed fraction of an animation to a value that represents the interpolated fraction.

This interpolated value is then multiplied by the change in value of an animation to derive the animated value at the current elapsed animation time.

Parameters:
inputA value between 0 and 1.0 indicating our current point in the animation where 0 represents the start and 1.0 represents the end
Returns:
The interpolation value. This value can be more than 1.0 for interpolators which overshoot their targets, or less than 0 for interpolators that undershoot their targets.

Implemented in gaia::core::AccelerateDecelerateInterpolator, gaia::core::AccelerateInterpolator, gaia::core::AnticipateInterpolator, gaia::core::AnticipateOvershootInterpolator, gaia::core::BounceInterpolator, gaia::core::CycleInterpolator, gaia::core::DecelerateInterpolator, gaia::core::IInterpolator, gaia::core::LinearInterpolator, and gaia::core::OvershootInterpolator.
